Award.AwardTitle: Structural Composites with High Biobased Content

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Materials derived from renewable resources have increasing interest today since they can help reduce our dependence on petrochemical based materials. With any new composite material system, understanding the properties as a function of matrix resin structure and composition as well as fiber type, surface functionalization, and fiber loading is critical. Thus, the focus of the project is to understand the impact of critical design variables on performance of composites using a new biobased resin system in combination with natural fibers as reinforcement. Preliminary experiments using this new resin system along with natural fibers have shown that the composites have promising structural properties and can lead to a biobased composite system with high biocontent, 60% or greater. Structure-property studies of the matrix resin system will be carried out to understand the impact of variables such as epoxy functionality, anhydride crosslinker, catalyst and loading, and curing conditions on properties such as modulus, impact resistance, glass transition temperature, thermal stability, water sorption, and durability. Composites with glass fiber reinforcement along with natural fibers will be prepared and the effect of fiber treatment, fiber loading on the properties will be evaluated. The durability of the matrix resin and resulting composite systems will be explored. Structure-process-property relationships will be established for the biocomposites produced with regards to durability for use as a structural construction grade material.

The use of materials derived largely from agricultural products is a key component of a sustainable future and can lead to a reduction of dependence on petrochemical derived materials, reduced energy usage, and a reduction in carbon emissions. The scientific results of this project can lead to the development of a new biobased structural composite material system meeting the goals of sustainability as well as the performance requirements for structural applications. The focus of the project is to understand the influence of each component of the biobased composite system (resin, fiber, and resin-fiber interface) on important properties of the composite as they relate to structural performance and durability.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall focus of the project was to understand the impact of critical design variables on the performance of composites made using a novel bio-based resin system with natural fiber reinforcement. The project goals were: 1. Understand the effect of composition variables on performance of the novel binder system; 2. Prepare, test, and evaluate bio-based structural composites.

The following scientific outcomes were achieved: 1. The kinetics of the curing of the novel epoxy-cyclic anhydride resin system using a zinc catalyst were fully elucidated; 2. The structure-property relationships of the resin system as a function of crosslinker amount and catalyst level were determined; 3. The use of linear polyanhydrides as curing agents was explored; 4. A wide variety of catalysts for the curing reaction were explored and several catalysts identified having greater activity than previous catalysts explored, leading to the ability to cure the composite at lower temperature/time; 5. A study of methods to improve the impact properties of the resin system and composites was carried out with several approaches appearing promising; 6. Composites using flax fiber reinforcement were produced that had mechanical properties that met or exceeded the benchmark established for use in structural applications; 7. Artificial weathering studies indicated that the new bio-based composite system retained gloss better than the control petrochemical system and maintained mechanical properties similar to the control petrochemical system;

The results of the project were disseminated through oral and poster presentations by the participating graduate students as well as the PIs at national and international meetings. A graduate student in the program led a session on polymers, paint and plastics for the Expanding Your Horizons program for girls in grades 7-9. 

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2015
Modified by: Dean C Webster

The structure-property relationships of the resin system as a function of crosslinker amount and catalyst level were determined; 3. The use of linear polyanhydrides as curing agents was explored; 4. A wide variety of catalysts for the curing reaction were explored and several catalysts identified having greater activity than previous catalysts explored, leading to the ability to cure the composite at lower temperature/time; 5. A study of methods to improve the impact properties of the resin system and composites was carried out with several approaches appearing promising; 6. Artificial weathering studies indicated that the new bio-based composite system retained gloss better than the control petrochemical system and maintained mechanical properties similar to the control petrochemical system; The results of the project were disseminated through oral and poster presentations by the participating graduate students as well as the PIs at national and international meetings. A graduate student in the program led a session on polymers, paint and plastics for the Expanding Your Horizons program for girls in grades 7-9.
